text: Sojourn in this land, and I will be with thee, and will bless thee; for unto thee, and unto thy seed, I will give all these countries, and I will perform the oath which I sware unto Abraham thy father;
text_kjv: Sojourn in this land, and I will be with thee, and will bless thee; for unto thee, and unto thy seed, I will give all these countries, and I will perform the oath which I sware unto Abraham thy father;
text_niv: Stay in this land for a while, and I will be with you and will bless you. For to you and your descendants I will give all these lands and will confirm the oath I swore to your father Abraham.
text_esv: Sojourn in this land, and I will be with you and will bless you, for to you and to your offspring I will give all these lands, and I will establish the oath that I swore to Abraham your father.
text_nlt: Live here as a foreigner in this land, and I will be with you and bless you. I hereby confirm that I will give all these lands to you and your descendants, just as I solemnly promised Abraham, your father.
text_msg: Stay here in this land and I'll be with you and bless you. I'm giving you and your children all these lands, fulfilling the oath that I swore to your father Abraham.
text_nasb: 'Sojourn in this land and I will be with you and bless you, for to you and to your descendants I will give all these lands, and I will establish the oath which I swore to your father Abraham.
context: Genesis 26 unfolds against the backdrop of a severe famine gripping the land of Canaan. This echoes the famine that drove Abraham to Egypt (Genesis 12:10), establishing a parallel between father and son and highlighting the recurring vulnerability of the patriarchs. Isaac, like his father before him, intends to descend into Egypt to escape the famine. However, God intervenes, instructing him to sojourn in the land of Gerar, which was Philistine territory. The Philistines, known for their maritime prowess and distinct culture, were a constant presence and often a source of tension for the Israelites. Gerar, ruled by Abimelech, represented a semi-nomadic society with established agricultural practices. Isaac's arrival as a relatively wealthy herdsman would have created both opportunities and challenges for the Philistines. The 'countries' mentioned in the verse refer not just to Canaan but potentially to surrounding territories that Abraham's descendants would eventually inherit, hinting at a larger, more extensive dominion promised by God. The 'oath' God swore to Abraham was a solemn covenant promising land, posterity, and blessing, which formed the foundation of the Abrahamic covenant and the future nation of Israel. The reaffirmation of this oath to Isaac emphasizes continuity and divine faithfulness.
meaning: Genesis 26:3 is a powerful affirmation of God's covenant faithfulness and his providential care for his chosen people. The command to 'Sojourn in this land' is not merely a geographical instruction but a test of Isaac's obedience and trust in God's provision. God's promise, 'I will be with thee, and will bless thee,' underscores the inseparable link between obedience and blessing. This presence isn't simply physical proximity but a manifestation of God's favor and guidance. The blessing encompasses material prosperity, protection from enemies, and spiritual enrichment. The reiteration of the promise concerning the land, 'unto thee, and unto thy seed, I will give all these countries,' reinforces the Abrahamic covenant's enduring significance. It's a reminder that God's promises are not contingent on human merit but are rooted in his sovereign grace and immutable character. The phrase 'I will perform the oath which I sware unto Abraham thy father' emphasizes the historical continuity of God's covenant and its unbreakable nature. This verse serves as a reminder that God's promises are intergenerational; they extend beyond individual lifetimes to impact future generations. It highlights the concept of covenantal theology, where God establishes relationships with individuals and their descendants, binding himself to fulfill his promises.
application: Genesis 26:3 speaks profoundly to the modern believer facing uncertainty and hardship. In a world marked by instability, economic anxieties, and personal crises, the promise, 'I will be with thee, and will bless thee,' offers unwavering hope. This verse encourages us to trust in God's provision even when circumstances seem bleak. It challenges us to remain steadfast in our faith, refusing to succumb to fear or despair. The command to 'Sojourn in this land' can be interpreted as a call to remain faithful in the place where God has planted us, even if it's uncomfortable or challenging. It might mean staying in a difficult job, persevering in a strained relationship, or serving in a community that presents unique obstacles. Obedience to God, even in the face of adversity, is the key to unlocking his blessing. We must seek his guidance through prayer and Scripture, discerning his will for our lives and aligning ourselves with his purposes. The reaffirmation of the promise to Abraham's seed reminds us that our actions today have consequences for future generations. We are called to live lives of integrity, faithfulness, and compassion, leaving a legacy of blessing for those who come after us. The concept of God's presence is not limited to dramatic spiritual experiences but permeates every aspect of our lives. He is with us in our joys and sorrows, our successes and failures. Cultivating a consistent awareness of his presence transforms our perspective, empowers us to overcome challenges, and enables us to live lives of purpose and meaning. Ultimately, this verse calls us to a life of radical trust, believing that God will fulfill his promises, even when we cannot see the way forward.
prayer: Heavenly Father, thank you for the unwavering promise of your presence. In times of uncertainty and fear, remind me of your faithfulness to Isaac and Abraham. Help me to trust in your provision, even when circumstances appear daunting. Give me the courage to sojourn in the place where you have planted me, even when it's uncomfortable or challenging. Grant me discernment to understand your will and the strength to obey it. May my life be a testament to your covenant faithfulness, leaving a legacy of blessing for generations to come. I surrender my anxieties and fears to you, trusting that you are in control. Fill me with your peace and grant me the confidence to walk in obedience, knowing that you are always with me. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: To sojourn means to reside temporarily in a place. In this context, it implies that Isaac should remain in Gerar as a resident alien, trusting in God's protection and provision rather than seeking a more permanent solution in Egypt. It signifies a commitment to staying where God directs, even amidst difficulty.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to 'sojourn' in this context?

faqs.answer: God likely prevented Isaac from going to Egypt to test his faith and obedience. Egypt represented a reliance on worldly solutions, while staying in Gerar required trusting God to provide in the midst of famine. It was about choosing divine dependence over human resourcefulness.
faqs.question: Q2: Why did God specifically tell Isaac not to go to Egypt?

faqs.answer: This verse is a direct reaffirmation of the Abrahamic covenant. It restates the promises of land, posterity, and God's blessing, specifically linking Isaac to the covenant made with his father, Abraham, emphasizing its continuation and enduring nature.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the Abrahamic covenant?

faqs.answer: God's presence signifies more than just physical proximity; it encompasses his favor, guidance, protection, and provision. It means that God will actively intervene in Isaac's life, ensuring his well-being and fulfilling his promises. This presence is a source of strength and encouragement.
faqs.question: Q4: What does it mean that God will 'be with' Isaac?

faqs.answer: The blessing encompasses both material and spiritual prosperity. It's about trusting God to provide for your needs, experiencing his favor in your endeavors, and growing in your relationship with him. Seek his guidance, obey his commands, and trust in his promises to experience his blessing in your life.
